name: Las Palmas
fun_fact: Fun fact: Las Palmas locals say they're 'more Canarian than gofio' - an ancient expression of pride referencing the roasted corn flour that sustained islanders for centuries, originally brought by the indigenous Guanche people.

hero_dishes.name: Papas Arrugadas con Mojo
hero_dishes.description: Small wrinkled potatoes boiled in seawater-level saltiness, served with two vibrant mojo sauces - red (rojo) with paprika and chili, green (verde) with cilantro and parsley
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditionally boiled in actual seawater by fishermen and farmers. The volcanic soil of the Canary Islands gives these potatoes a unique flavor that makes them central to every meal - locals say 'if papas arrugadas aren't part of the meal, you haven't eaten'
hero_dishes.where_to_find: BodegÃ³n Pachichi in Las Palmas is famous for their mojo picÃ³n, so popular locals buy half-liter takeaway portions

hero_dishes.name: Gofio
hero_dishes.description: Roasted corn or grain flour that's mixed into everything - stirred into warm milk for breakfast, shaped into dough balls (pella) to eat with meals, or made into gofio escaldado with fish broth
hero_dishes.origin_story: The staple food of Canarians for centuries, so iconic there's an expression 'I'm more Canarian than gofio.' Still produced locally and added to countless dishes
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Available at Mercado Central in Las Palmas and used in traditional dishes at local tascas

hero_dishes.name: Ropa Vieja
hero_dishes.description: Hearty stew made with meat, vegetables, potatoes and chickpeas - the most popular dish in the Canary Islands
hero_dishes.origin_story: Name means 'old clothes' because it was traditionally made from leftovers, transforming yesterday's meal into today's comfort food
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Canarian restaurants throughout Las Palmas serve this as a daily staple

hero_dishes.name: Sancocho Canario
hero_dishes.description: Light, healthy dish of broiled whole fish served alongside papas arrugadas and gofio
hero_dishes.origin_story: Reflects the Canarian dependence on fresh local seafood, prepared simply to let the fish shine
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Coastal restaurants and tascas in Las Palmas' fishing neighborhoods

hero_dishes.name: Queso Asado
hero_dishes.description: Soft but firm goat or sheep cheese, grilled to perfection with a crispy crust on the outside
hero_dishes.origin_story: Canary Islands have a long tradition of raising goats and sheep, mastering artisanal cheese-making over centuries
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mercado Central, San Mateo market, Mercadillo de Teror, and Recova de GÃ¡ldar for artisan cheeses

signature_drinks.name: Ron Miel (Honey Rum)
signature_drinks.description: Sweet golden liqueur made from rum blended with at least 2% natural Canarian honey, ranging from 20-45% alcohol
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served ice-cold as shots with a sprinkle of lime juice, or as an aperitif/digestif. Ron Miel Guanche is the most consumed liqueur in Gran Canaria. The iconic Arehucas Distillery has been making it since 1885

signature_drinks.name: Tropical Beer
signature_drinks.description: The pride of Las Palmas and Gran Canaria's local brewery
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served cold with tapas and traditional dishes, especially popular in beach-side bars

signature_drinks.name: Cidre Breton with Currant Liqueur
signature_drinks.description: Breton cider mixed with blackcurrant liqueur
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Popular aperitif in Las Palmas' bars

food_culture_notes: Papas arrugadas appear at every meal - locals consider them as essential as pasta is to Italians
Mojo sauce originated in the Canary Islands and spread worldwide - two varieties (red and green) are served with almost everything
The volcanic soil gives Canarian potatoes and produce a unique flavor found nowhere else
Ron Miel has protected EU status - only Canarian-made honey rum can use this name
Traditional tascas (small bars) serve local dishes in authentic settings with locals buying mojo sauce to-go
Markets like Mercado Central are central to food culture, selling fresh local produce and artisan cheeses
